metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and analyse theoretically and practically the force on a current carrying conductor due to an external magnetic field, F = nIlB, where the directions of I and B are either perpendicular or parallel to each other

magnetic_force_formula.name: Magnetic Force Formula
magnetic_force_formula.correct: The magnetic force on a current-carrying conductor is F = nIlB, where n is the number of wires, I is current, l is length in the field, and B is field strength.

F = IlB.error: Missing n. This only works for a single wire.
F = IlB.fix: F = nIlB includes n for multiple wires. For one wire, n = 1.
F = IlB.action: Check: are there multiple wires? If so, include n.

F = nIl/B.error: B should be multiplied, not divided.
F = nIl/B.fix: Stronger field = greater force. F is proportional to B.
F = nIl/B.action: Check: does a stronger magnet give more force? Yes, so F is proportional to B.

F = nI²lB.error: Current is not squared in this formula.
F = nI²lB.fix: F = nIlB. Power formulas have I squared, but not force formulas.
F = nI²lB.action: Don't confuse with P = I²R. Force has I to the first power.

persistent.gap: You're not remembering the force formula correctly.
persistent.action: Write F = nIlB and identify each variable: n (wires), I (current), l (length), B (field).

force_proportionality.name: Force Proportionality
force_proportionality.formula: F proportional to n, I, l, B
force_proportionality.correct: Magnetic force is directly proportional to number of wires, current, length, and field strength.

inversely proportional to current.fix: F = nIlB shows F is proportional to I. Double current, double force.
inversely proportional to current.action: Check units: F = nIlB gives N = (A)(m)(T). I is in numerator.

inversely proportional to field strength.fix: F = nIlB shows F is proportional to B. Stronger magnets give bigger forces.
inversely proportional to field strength.action: Think practically: moving a wire near a stronger magnet feels more pull.

independent of length.error: Wrong. Longer wire in field = more force.
independent of length.fix: F = nIlB shows F is proportional to l. More wire exposed = more force.
independent of length.action: Only the length INSIDE the field counts. Double that length, double the force.

proportional to length squared.fix: F = nIlB has l to the first power, not l squared.
proportional to length squared.action: Check formula: no squares on any variable in F = nIlB.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how F depends on each variable.
persistent.action: Make a table showing what happens to F when you double each variable separately.

right_hand_rule.name: Right-Hand Palm Rule
right_hand_rule.formula: Thumb = I, Fingers = B, Palm = F
right_hand_rule.correct: Point thumb in direction of conventional current, fingers in direction of magnetic field. Palm pushes in direction of force.

thumb points to field.error: Thumb is for current, not field.
thumb points to field.fix: Thumb = current direction. Fingers = field direction.
thumb points to field.action: Remember: Thumb for flow (current). Fingers for Field.

fingers point to current.error: Fingers are for field, not current.
fingers point to current.fix: Fingers = field direction. Thumb = current direction.
fingers point to current.action: Fingers = Field (both start with F). Thumb = current.

back of hand shows force.error: Palm shows force direction, not back of hand.
back of hand shows force.fix: The palm pushes in the direction the wire is pushed.
back of hand shows force.action: Imagine pushing the wire. Your palm does the pushing.

use left hand for current.error: Always use right hand for conventional current.
use left hand for current.fix: Right-hand rule for positive/conventional current direction.
use left hand for current.action: Left hand is for electron flow. Right hand for conventional current.

persistent.gap: You're not applying the right-hand palm rule correctly.
persistent.action: Practice with 10 examples. Thumb = I, Fingers = B, Palm = F. Draw each.

perpendicular_condition.name: Perpendicular Condition
perpendicular_condition.formula: Maximum force when I perpendicular to B
perpendicular_condition.correct: The force formula F = nIlB applies when current is perpendicular to the magnetic field. This gives maximum force.

applies when I is parallel to B.error: No force when parallel. Formula gives maximum when perpendicular.
applies when I is parallel to B.fix: Perpendicular = maximum force. Parallel = zero force.
applies when I is parallel to B.action: Try the right-hand rule with parallel I and B. Your palm can't point anywhere useful.

applies at any angle.error: F = nIlB only for perpendicular. Other angles need F = nIlB sin theta.
applies at any angle.fix: VCE only considers perpendicular or parallel cases.
applies at any angle.action: At 90 degrees: F = nIlB. At 0 or 180 degrees: F = 0. Nothing in between for VCE.

gives minimum force.fix: Minimum is zero (when parallel). Maximum is at 90 degrees.

persistent.gap: You don't understand when the force formula applies.
persistent.action: Draw wire and field at 0, 45, 90 degrees. Force is max at 90, zero at 0.

parallel_condition.name: Parallel Condition
parallel_condition.formula: Zero force when I parallel to B
parallel_condition.correct: When current flows parallel or anti-parallel to the magnetic field, there is no magnetic force on the wire.

maximum force when parallel.fix: No force when I parallel to B. Maximum when I perpendicular to B.
maximum force when parallel.action: Try right-hand rule with thumb and fingers in same direction. Palm points nowhere.

half the maximum force.error: Not half. Zero force when parallel.
half the maximum force.action: It's all or nothing: perpendicular (max) or parallel (zero).

force acts along the wire.error: No force at all when parallel, in any direction.
force acts along the wire.fix: Magnetic force is always perpendicular to both B and I. When these are parallel, there's no perpendicular direction possible.
force acts along the wire.action: Think about cross product: parallel vectors give zero.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why parallel alignment gives zero force.
persistent.action: The magnetic force needs to be perpendicular to both I and B. When they're parallel, that's impossible.

variable_identification.name: Variable Identification
variable_identification.formula: n = wires, I = current, l = length, B = field
variable_identification.correct: In F = nIlB: n is number of wires, I is current in amps, l is length of wire in the field in metres, B is magnetic field strength in tesla.

l is total wire length.error: Only the length INSIDE the magnetic field counts.
l is total wire length.fix: If wire extends beyond the magnet, only measure the part in the field.
l is total wire length.action: Draw a wire passing through a region of field. l is only that section.

n is number of electrons.error: n is number of wires, not electrons.
n is number of electrons.fix: Think of n as counting parallel wires in a bundle or turns in a coil.
n is number of electrons.action: For a single wire, n = 1. For 10 wires in parallel, n = 10.

B is measured in gauss.error: SI unit is tesla, not gauss.
B is measured in gauss.fix: 1 T = 10,000 gauss. Always use tesla in VCE.
B is measured in gauss.action: Check units: F(N) = n times I(A) times l(m) times B(T).

I is electron current.error: I is conventional current, which flows opposite to electrons.
I is electron current.fix: Conventional current flows from + to minus. Electron flow is opposite.
I is electron current.action: Use conventional current direction for right-hand rule.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the variables in the force formula.
persistent.action: Write out: n = wires, I = current (A), l = length in field (m), B = field (T).

force_direction_determination.name: Force Direction Determination
force_direction_determination.formula: F perpendicular to both I and B
force_direction_determination.correct: The magnetic force is always perpendicular to both the current direction and the magnetic field direction.

parallel to the current.error: Force is perpendicular to current, not parallel.
parallel to the current.fix: Magnetic force cannot accelerate charges along their direction of motion.
parallel to the current.action: Use right-hand rule: palm (force) is perpendicular to thumb (current).

parallel to the field.error: Force is perpendicular to field, not parallel.
parallel to the field.fix: Force is perpendicular to both I and B.
parallel to the field.action: Palm (force) is perpendicular to fingers (field) in right-hand rule.

at 45 degrees to the field.error: Always exactly perpendicular, not at any other angle.
at 45 degrees to the field.fix: The cross product I cross B is always perpendicular to both.
at 45 degrees to the field.action: Check: force, current, and field form a 3D right-angle system.

opposite to the current.error: Not opposite. Perpendicular (90 degrees), not anti-parallel (180 degrees).
opposite to the current.fix: Force is at right angles to current, not reversing it.
opposite to the current.action: Use right-hand rule to find actual direction.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the geometry of magnetic forces.
persistent.action: Draw 3D axes: I, B, and F are all mutually perpendicular.

unit_analysis.name: Unit Analysis
unit_analysis.formula: N = A times m times T
unit_analysis.correct: Force in newtons equals (number)(amps)(metres)(tesla). Tesla is defined as T = N/(A times m), which makes the units work.

force in joules.fix: Force is measured in newtons (N). Work/energy is in joules (J).
force in joules.action: F = nIlB gives force (N). W = Fd gives energy (J).

field in gauss.error: Use SI units. Tesla, not gauss.
field in gauss.fix: 1 T = 10,000 G. Always convert to tesla.
field in gauss.action: Gauss is CGS. Tesla is SI. VCE uses SI.

current in coulombs.error: Coulombs are charge. Current is in amps.
current in coulombs.action: Amps measure charge flow rate. Coulombs measure total charge.

length in centimetres.error: Use SI units. Metres, not centimetres.
length in centimetres.fix: Convert cm to m: divide by 100.
length in centimetres.action: 10 cm = 0.10 m. Always use metres in F = nIlB.

persistent.gap: You need to be more careful with units.
persistent.action: Always check: F(N) = n times I(A) times l(m) times B(T). Convert before substituting.

current_carrying_wire_model.name: Current-Carrying Wire Model
current_carrying_wire_model.formula: Wire force = sum of charge forces
current_carrying_wire_model.correct: A current-carrying wire experiences force because the moving charges inside it each experience magnetic force, and these add up across the whole wire.

the wire itself is magnetic.error: The wire isn't inherently magnetic. The moving charges cause the force.
the wire itself is magnetic.fix: Moving charges in the current experience F = qvB. This transfers to the wire.
the wire itself is magnetic.action: Turn off the current. Does the wire still feel a force? No.

only the electrons feel the force.error: Electrons feel force, but it's transmitted to the wire structure.
only the electrons feel the force.fix: Electrons can't leave the wire, so when pushed, the whole wire moves.
only the electrons feel the force.action: The force on electrons becomes force on wire because electrons are trapped in it.

the field exerts force directly on the m.error: Field acts on moving charges, not on metal atoms.
the field exerts force directly on the m.fix: Stationary charges and neutral atoms don't experience magnetic force.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why current-carrying wires experience magnetic force.
persistent.action: Trace the logic: moving electrons then each feels F = qvB then electrons push wire then wire moves.

multiple_wires.name: Multiple Wires Effect
multiple_wires.correct: For n parallel wires each carrying current I, the total force is n times the force on one wire: F = nIlB.

force is the same regardless of n.fix: Each wire contributes its own force. Total force = n times single wire force.
force is the same regardless of n.action: Calculate force for 1 wire, then multiply by n.

force is proportional to n squared.fix: F = nIlB shows F is proportional to n (first power).
force is proportional to n squared.action: Double the wires, double the force. Not quadruple.

only the outer wires feel force.error: All wires in the field experience force.
only the outer wires feel force.fix: Each wire carrying current in a magnetic field experiences F = IlB.
only the outer wires feel force.action: Inner and outer wires all contribute. That's why n matters.

n only applies to coils.error: n applies to any bundle of parallel wires.
n only applies to coils.fix: Coils have n turns. Wire bundles have n wires. Same formula.
n only applies to coils.action: Count parallel current paths. That's your n.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how multiple wires affect total force.
persistent.action: Think of it as n separate forces adding up: F_total = F1 + F2 + ... + Fn = nIlB.

magnetic_field_strength.name: Magnetic Field Strength
magnetic_field_strength.correct: Magnetic field strength B is measured in tesla (T). One tesla is a very strong field. Earth's field is about 50 microtesla.

measured in webers.error: Webers measure magnetic flux, not field strength.
measured in webers.fix: Flux (Phi) is in webers (Wb). B (field) is in tesla (T).
measured in webers.action: B = Flux/A, so T = Wb/m squared.

Earth's field is about 1 T.error: Earth's field is much weaker: about 50 microtesla.
Earth's field is about 1 T.fix: 1 T is very strong (MRI machines). Earth is 0.00005 T.
Earth's field is about 1 T.action: Typical values: Earth about 50 microtesla, fridge magnet about 5 mT, MRI about 3 T.

stronger field means less force.fix: F = nIlB shows F is proportional to B. Bigger B, bigger F.
stronger field means less force.action: Double the field strength, double the force.

field strength depends on current.error: B is the external field, set by the magnet. I is in the wire.
field strength depends on current.fix: B is from the magnets creating the field. I is what flows in your wire.
field strength depends on current.action: B and I are independent. You control I; the magnet sets B.

persistent.gap: You're confusing field strength with other magnetic quantities.
persistent.action: Remember: B (field, tesla) vs Flux (flux, weber) vs F (force, newton).

practical_considerations.name: Practical Considerations
practical_considerations.correct: Only the portion of wire actually inside the magnetic field region experiences force. Wire outside the field contributes nothing.

total wire length matters.error: Only the length inside the field counts.
total wire length matters.fix: Wire outside the field has B = 0, so no force contribution.
total wire length matters.action: Draw the field region. Measure only the wire inside it.

force acts on the whole circuit.error: Force only acts where wire is in the field.
force acts on the whole circuit.fix: Parts of circuit outside the field feel no magnetic force.
force acts on the whole circuit.action: Identify which segments are in the field. Calculate force for each.

wire must form a complete loop.error: Any current-carrying wire in a field feels force, loop or not.
wire must form a complete loop.fix: F = nIlB works for straight wires, loops, or any shape.
wire must form a complete loop.action: You need current flow, but it doesn't have to be a visible loop.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying which part of the wire experiences force.
persistent.action: Always draw: (1) the wire, (2) the field region, (3) measure only the overlap.

force_formula.title: Understanding the Force Formula
force_formula.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of the magnetic force on current-carrying conductors.

sentences.text: A current-carrying wire placed in a magnetic field experiences a force because the {{d1}} inside the wire are pushed by the magnetic field, and this force is transferred to the {{d2}} itself.

d1.tooltip: What carries electric current in a wire?

d2.tooltip: Where do the charges transfer their force?

sentences.text: The magnitude of the magnetic force on a current-carrying conductor is given by the formula F = {{d3}}, where I represents {{d4}} and B represents {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: All variables are multiplied together with first powers.

d4.tooltip: I measures the rate of charge flow.

d5.tooltip: B is the field strength, measured in T.

sentences.text: In the formula F = nIlB, the variable n represents {{d6}}, and the variable l represents the {{d7}} of wire within the magnetic field region.

distractors: number of turns in the magnet
d6.tooltip: Count parallel wires carrying the same current.

d7.tooltip: Only the portion inside the field counts.

direction.title: Determining Force Direction
direction.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of how to find the direction of the magnetic force.

sentences.text: The direction of the magnetic force on a current-carrying wire can be found using the right-hand {{d1}} rule, where the thumb points in the direction of {{d2}} and the fingers point in the direction of the {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: Which right-hand rule is used for forces on wires?

sentences.text: When using the right-hand palm rule, the {{d4}} of your hand indicates the direction of the magnetic force. This force is always {{d5}} to both the current direction and the magnetic field direction.

d4.tooltip: Which part of the hand shows force direction?

d5.tooltip: The force forms a right angle with both I and B.

sentences.text: The magnetic force direction is {{d6}} to the direction of motion of the charges, which means the magnetic field cannot change the {{d7}} of the charges, only their direction.

d6.tooltip: At what angle is force to velocity?

perpendicular_parallel.title: Perpendicular and Parallel Cases
perpendicular_parallel.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of the angle between current and field.

sentences.text: The formula F = nIlB applies when the current is {{d1}} to the magnetic field. In this orientation, the force on the wire is at its {{d2}} value.

d1.tooltip: At what angle does F = nIlB apply directly?

sentences.text: When the current flows parallel to the magnetic field, the magnetic force on the wire equals {{d3}}. This is because the angle between I and B is {{d4}} degrees.

d4.tooltip: Parallel means aligned in the same direction.

sentences.text: In VCE Physics, only two orientations are considered: current {{d5}} to the field (maximum force) and current {{d6}} to the field (zero force).

d6.tooltip: 0 or 180 degree orientation gives zero force.

applications.title: Applying the Force Formula
applications.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your ability to apply the magnetic force concepts.

sentences.text: A bundle of 10 wires, each carrying 2.0 A, is placed perpendicular to a 0.050 T magnetic field. If 2.0 m of the bundle is in the field, the force is found by using n = {{d1}} in the formula F = nIlB.

d1.tooltip: How many wires are in the bundle?

sentences.text: If the current in a wire is doubled while all other factors remain constant, the magnetic force will {{d2}}. If the magnetic field strength is halved, the force will {{d3}}.

d2.tooltip: F is directly proportional to I.

d3.tooltip: F is directly proportional to B.

sentences.text: When calculating the magnetic force, the length l must be measured in {{d4}} and the magnetic field B must be measured in {{d5}} to get force in newtons.

d4.tooltip: SI unit for length is metres.

d5.tooltip: SI unit for magnetic field strength.

force_formula.title: Applying the Force Formula
force_formula.instructions: Apply your understanding of the magnetic force formula to these scenarios.

sentences.text: The reason a current-carrying wire experiences force in a magnetic field is that each {{d1}} moving through the wire experiences an individual magnetic force, and these forces combine to push the {{d2}} structure.

d1.tooltip: Which particles actually move in a current-carrying wire?

d2.tooltip: Where does the force end up being applied?

sentences.text: A wire carrying 5.0 A is placed in a uniform magnetic field of 0.20 T. If 0.30 m of the wire is inside the field region and perpendicular to it, the force on the wire is {{d3}} N. If there were 4 such wires, the total force would be {{d4}} N.

d4.tooltip: Multiply single wire force by n = 4.

sentences.text: The magnetic force is directly proportional to {{d5}}, meaning that tripling the current will {{d6}} the force, assuming all other factors remain unchanged.

d5.tooltip: Which variable appears linearly in F = nIlB?

d6.tooltip: F is proportional to I means F scales linearly with I.

direction.title: Applying Force Direction Rules
direction.instructions: Apply your understanding of the right-hand rule to determine force directions.

sentences.text: A wire carries current to the right in a magnetic field pointing into the page. Using the right-hand palm rule with thumb to the {{d1}} and fingers into the page, the palm points {{d2}}, indicating the force direction.

d2.tooltip: Palm shows force direction when thumb and fingers are set.

sentences.text: If the current direction is reversed while keeping the magnetic field the same, the force direction will {{d3}}. Similarly, if only the magnetic field direction is reversed, the force direction will also {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Reversing either I or B reverses F.

d4.tooltip: F depends on both I and B directions.

sentences.text: The magnetic force cannot do {{d5}} on the moving charges because it acts {{d6}} to their motion, which only changes their direction, not their energy.

d5.tooltip: W = Fd cos theta. What happens when theta = 90?

d6.tooltip: At what angle is force to velocity?

perpendicular_parallel.title: Orientation Effects on Force
perpendicular_parallel.instructions: Apply your understanding of how orientation affects the magnetic force.

sentences.text: A wire carrying 3.0 A enters a 0.50 T magnetic field. When the wire is perpendicular to the field, the force per metre of wire is {{d1}} N/m. When rotated to be parallel to the field, the force becomes {{d2}} N/m.

d2.tooltip: No force when current is parallel to field.

sentences.text: The zero force case occurs when current and field are {{d3}}, because there is no component of charge velocity {{d4}} to the field in this orientation.

d3.tooltip: At what alignment is there no force?

sentences.text: In a DC motor, the coil sides experience maximum force when the plane of the coil is {{d5}} to the magnetic field, corresponding to current being {{d6}} to the field.

d5.tooltip: When is force on the sides maximum?

d6.tooltip: Maximum force needs I perpendicular to B.

applications.title: Real-World Applications
applications.instructions: Apply the magnetic force concepts to practical situations.

sentences.text: A coil with 50 turns carries 2.0 A in a 0.10 T field. If each side of the coil in the field is 0.20 m long, the force on one side is F = {{d1}} times 2.0 times 0.20 times 0.10 = {{d2}} N.

d1.tooltip: How many turns does the coil have?

sentences.text: If a 0.15 m wire experiences a force of 0.30 N when carrying 4.0 A perpendicular to a magnetic field, the field strength is B = F/(nIl) = {{d3}} T.
The Earth's magnetic field is approximately {{d4}} T, which is much {{d5}} than typical laboratory magnets (around 0.01 to 1 T).

force_formula.title: Mastering the Force Formula
force_formula.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of the magnetic force concepts.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that the wire itself is magnetic. The actual reason for the force is that {{d1}} experience F = qvB, and since they cannot leave the wire, this becomes a macroscopic force of F = {{d2}} on the conductor.

d1.tooltip: What actually feels the magnetic force first?

d2.tooltip: The macroscopic formula for wire force.

sentences.text: Comparing F = qvB for a single charge to F = nIlB for a wire: the current I = nq/t represents many charges, and the length l = vt captures the {{d3}} of charges in the field. This shows why F = nIlB is just F = qvB applied to {{d4}} charges.

d3.tooltip: What property of charge motion does length capture?

sentences.text: If force on a 20 cm wire is 0.40 N when carrying 5.0 A in a field, and the wire has 8 strands, then B = F/(nIl) = 0.40/(8 times 5.0 times {{d5}}) = {{d6}} T.

direction.title: Complete Direction Analysis
direction.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of force direction concepts.

sentences.text: When both the current direction AND the magnetic field direction are reversed simultaneously, the force direction {{d1}} because reversing both factors reverses the result {{d2}}.

A student incorrectly uses their left hand for the palm rule with conventional current. Their predicted force direction will be {{d3}} to the actual direction. This error can be avoided by always using the {{d4}} hand.

d3.tooltip: Left hand gives mirror image of right hand.

sentences.text: In a current balance experiment, the force on a wire is balanced against gravity. If the wire's weight is 0.015 N and it balances when carrying 3.0 A through 0.10 m in a field, then B = 0.015/(1 times 3.0 times 0.10) = {{d5}} T.

perpendicular_parallel.title: Orientation Mastery
perpendicular_parallel.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of perpendicular and parallel cases.

sentences.text: The general formula F = nIlB sin theta reduces to F = nIlB when theta = {{d1}} degrees and to F = 0 when theta = {{d2}} degrees. VCE only requires these two cases.
A rectangular coil has sides AB and CD parallel to the field, and sides BC and DA perpendicular to it. The force on AB and CD is {{d3}}, while BC and DA experience {{d4}} force.

d3.tooltip: Current parallel to field gives what force?

d4.tooltip: Current perpendicular to field gives what force?

sentences.text: The forces on opposite sides of a current loop in a uniform field are equal in magnitude but {{d5}} in direction. This creates a {{d6}} that makes the loop rotate.

d5.tooltip: Current flows opposite ways on opposite sides.

d6.tooltip: Equal and opposite forces at different locations create what?

applications.title: Advanced Applications
applications.instructions: Apply your complete understanding to complex scenarios.

sentences.text: An electric motor coil has n = 200 turns, carries I = 0.50 A, has sides l = 0.080 m in a field B = 0.30 T. The maximum force on one side is F = {{d1}} N. This creates maximum torque when the coil plane is {{d2}} to the field.

d2.tooltip: When is force on sides maximum?

sentences.text: Two parallel wires carrying currents in the same direction will {{d3}} each other. This is because each wire creates a magnetic field that exerts a force on the {{d4}} in the other wire.

d4.tooltip: What does the magnetic field act on?

sentences.text: The definition of the ampere uses the force between parallel wires: 1 A is defined such that two infinite wires 1 m apart, each carrying 1 A, experience a force of {{d5}} N per metre of length.

d5.tooltip: This is the SI definition of the ampere.
